text: um good morning everyone um it's lovely to attend my first ndc um
today and get to speak to you all about design um
so design for developers is a bit of a whistle-stop tour um of design principles and applications
especially relevant to the web um so i wanted to write this talk um because i've worked with a lot of
front-end developers in the past who've asked me to share some tips and tricks um on how they can create better designs
sometimes it's because they've wanted to create designs for themselves or projects they're working on and
sometimes it's because they've had no other choice but to be the designer and so whoever you are and whatever you
do i'm very grateful you're here um so who am i i'm lex lofthouse i use she her pronouns
and my handle on almost everything is at lofty loftio and i'm a designer
i have been for over 10 years now um i originally studied graphic design up in scotland and i moved down to
nottingham in 2011 to pursue a career in design i now work at a digital agency called
enzyme who are based in nottingham um there and throughout my career i've specialized in web design but also brand
and print and all sorts of other kind of design as well so
starting with a preface um but i feel like this is important i've got an hour here so i'm not going
to teach you everything that i've learned about design over the last kind of decade um and it's not a
comprehensive overview of everything it takes to be a designer but i think we all know that i'm also not going to teach any
code-based technique i don't really code very well um most of the time i hand my
designs over to front-end developer so who am i to tell you how to do that
um so what this talk is i'm going to be going through some fundamental design principles first of all
some common design elements and tips on how to implement those and lastly i'm going to go through some kind of before
and after examples on how we can refine existing designs for the front end as well so let's get started
so i want to start with the basics so this is principles of design and that are important to follow so
there is no real law on how many principles of design there are and some will say there is three four five six
seven eight and so on um but i feel like four is probably enough
and relevant enough for you to consider when it comes to designing for the web so those four elements are
hierarchy proximity contrast and balance so let's have a look into
what each of these mean so hierarchy similar to how we think of hierarchy in business and society and
nature it's a system in which things are arranged based on their importance so in design we achieve this
visually by creating elements and putting them in a clear order of priority
and so in development as well a common way we see this is with headings for example
you know h1 h2 h3 usually visually styled to follow that naming convention in
order of hierarchy it's a relatively simple principle to implement within design
because there are quite a few ways to do it one of the most common being scale for example the biggest thing on the page is
going to be the most important so that's principle one our second is
proximity so proximity is part of a larger set of principles called gestalt principles
so early in the 20th century psychologists studied how humans made sense of the world
and decided how we decide that things belong together um so
they found that the proximity of objects had a big part in that so when it comes to design
um for proximity we look at the content and we understand the relationship that these pieces of content have to each
other and we place them together in a way that makes sense so the distance between objects or the
lack of really helps us understand contents connection to each other
helps us group things on a page or screen for example in order to demonstrate that
so to use text as an example again if we have a heading and a paragraph of text sitting closely
underneath that you can probably safely say those things belong together and that heading is probably introducing
what that piece of copy says so proximity next principle is contrast so
contrast is a principle we use to emphasize objects in our design
this is achieved by having things be the opposite to each other or close enough to appear opposite
and we use that to highlight certain elements against one another for emphasis so contrast again
can be used in different ways um sometimes we use it for emphasis um and
in some ways that kind of relates back to the hierarchy principle too we might really want to highlight
something on the page by contrasting it with something else making it stand out other times contrast is just a crucial
part of the interface um again if we go back to text white text on a black background or vice
versa um just makes stuff really easy to read and that's contrast
so it doesn't always apply to color either it can be achieved in other ways such as using kind of juxtaposing font
choices different scales and shapes the key thing about contrast is that it
helps the user know where to look it creates a form of visual impact that draws the eye
okay last principle is balance so there's two types of balance
when we talk about design principles there is symmetrical balance and there's asymmetrical balance
so both rely on elements working alongside each other and balance really provides
a structure to your layout it's weight distributed um across your design by the placement
of elements so symmetrical balance means you've got a design that's quite evenly displayed
often with a kind of invisible center line down the middle um and this relies on elements being equal to each other on
both sides it's like a balance that scales um it's quite a satisfactory and consistent
layout and it's quite easy to get right asymmetrical balance on the other hand
is a bit more about tension elements kind of offset each other a little more
and it has a kind of unequal weight it offers a bit more of a dynamic layout
feeling of movement but it's a little trickier to get right so
those are our four design principles and the idea is to always kind of keep these in mind um they're the kind of key to
creating a good design um so when you're working on design keep these at the back of your mind if we're talking in terms
of lego these are kind of like the instructions and what i'm going to move on to next is
the actual lego blocks so that is the design elements is what
i'm going to call them um the bits that you need to build the layout
so again keeping this simple let's split this into four key areas we've got typography
we've got color imagery and layout so these four visual design
elements implemented alongside our principles are the kind of key to creating a great
interface so four principles four elements easy peasy
um so i want to run through what each of these are and some good tips um
to use for each of these so let's start with typography what is typography it is
the art and technique of arranging type so step one in typography is fonts
so a lot goes into typography and it isn't just limited to your font choices
but it does include them so it's a good place to start so depending on what you're working on
you might not need to choose fonts you might be really lucky and not have to choose them yourself and you might be
working with a brand that already has that set but you may be faced with a choice yourself so how do you do this
typically i'd suggest choosing a font pairing for your project
so this is what i would call easy mode for choosing fonts choose one font for headings and choose one font for body
copy so for headings you can be a bit braver with this choice this usually applies to
content that is shorter larger more attention grabbing you can choose a font that really represents the brand but is
also a bit more stylized a bit more decorative
when it comes to body copy we need to go a bit more simpler for it this text is usually in large paragraphs and it needs
to be easy to read especially at smaller sizes and so for this one
choose this more simple font for this and make sure you test it at the smaller sizes too
so as a bit of a starting point of where to find some fonts my go-to is google fonts which some designers would be oh
but it's free to use these fonts they're small file sizes and
there is loads of choices over a thousand fonts on there um and you can
narrow these down as well so good resource
so we need this heading in this body copy to work in harmony so how do we do
that that kind of comes down to the type of brand or product or whatever that
you're working for um fonts should kind of especially the heading font should embody that brand
and or complement the style and tone of that brand if you have a tech brand for example a
font that has a nice modern feel to it is good if you're working with a brand
for kids for example you might want a more fun maybe rounded font for that it
just helps convey that brown tone you wouldn't use say comic sans for a
really important warning sign or would you so i just want to show you some examples
of some good font pairings in the next few slides that can help you kind of make some of these decisions and i'm
going to use some famous nottingham landmarks because that is where i am from um so here's an example for nottingham
castle now this location has heritage it has history so i've chosen that heading font
to kind of echo the type style of that era it's got a good character to it and it works quite well as that heading font
and the body copy font below is just kind of classic serif font um it's simple it's easy to read at small sizes
and they pair really well together because of that secondly
this is not in contemporary is an art gallery um so here we're looking at a kind of modern style of font um here for the
heading it's bold quite eye-catching again has some really nice character to it um but it also represents a more
modern style of type like the gallery is and i've paired this with a sans-serif
font so less decorative this complements that modern style of
type again it's also really easy to read once we go down to smaller sizes
and the last one here is attenborough nature reserve so this is a kind of nature center near me um so i've chosen
this heading style because it's quite a fun display font it wouldn't work as the body copy but it works great as headings
it gives that natural kind of feel and then i've paired this with a serif font here but equally i think this could
work with say the font from the art gallery as well because there is not one right answer
when it comes to design but there are some wrong ones like that comic sans example so it's just thinking about the
type of brand that you're working for so to give your hand with font pairing stuff there is a tool for that i have
lots of resources in this um so this is fontjoy.com um it helps you pick some
font pairings and trial them um in the browser before you go ahead and kind of commit to
downloading fonts and all sorts so great tool for that so say we've got our font pairing chosen
now what do we do with them well we need to set up some styles so headings you've chosen your font
let's let's set up our heading styles now we need to
keep that hierarchy principle in mind when we do this so i've got two examples here of how you
can do that using the same font our example on the left it just uses scale
here to achieve that level of hierarchy heading one obviously being the largest and going down but our example on the
right also shows how we can add a little bit more interest again we're using the same font we're just styling it slightly differently we
have one in italics we have one in all caps with a bit more letter spacing there
um so let's have a look at body copy now
so body copy is slightly easier to get right usually i pick a kind of regular
paragraph size to use but also it's good to set up a larger one as well
and we can always add more styles um as we need throughout the design but giving yourself a good starting point here is
good so when it comes to setting sizes and scales another resource here uh type
pythonscale.com this again lets you set a kind of base level um and helps you scale up those
headings but you can also um have a look at what your body copy sizes are like so another great tool to
experiment with so now we've got our fonts and we've got our sizes the last thing we need to do
is figure out how we set the spacing now this sounds really boring but it's really important
and it's often overlooked so firstly line height so this is the spaces between continuous lines of copy
here i've got three examples kind of goldilocks situation here to show the
line height examples on this end of the scale the line height is very
small it makes the text really difficult to read everything's bunched up together it's not enough
and sometimes our default line spacing can look like this and we need to adjust it on the other end of the spectrum is this
the line height is huge my old design mentor used to tell me off for doing this and said you could fit a bus
through those lines um again in a different way it makes this harder to read you have to cast
your eye down further to find the next line so middle ground of our two examples this
is a bit more like we want to aim for and there's enough space to make it easy to read
on there the space that we don't use is just as important as the space we do so it's important to get that right comes down
to that proximity principle things are too far away from each other they don't belong in our brains
and secondly is paragraph spacing so this is the spacing before and after paragraphs
so here we have two examples the one on the left is a bad example and the one on the right is more along the
lines of what we want to achieve so on the right are spacing between the
paragraphs and after the heading should be about the same
this proximity makes it so that these things belong together with enough pause between
paragraphs and then after the paragraph that just needs to increase a little bit
more so that we can separate these two paragraphs um here but also have the headings
belong to those paragraphs of text we compare this to our example on the left we can kind of see why that
spacing's so important the proximities are all off and who knows what belongs to what um on
that example there so it's really key to helping users digest content if we think about that
proximity principle so we've got some typography examples under
our belt let's move on to the next design element so that's color
so what i want to talk about today is tips around how to create a color palette
to use across your design so similarly to our fonts you might have a bit of a starting point with a color
palette you might have an entire one to work from but you might be stuck with nothing
scary so how do we choose colors my tip is to start with one
because choosing an entire color palette from scratch can be quite daunting if you have one you can start to build
on that from there so the main color that you want to choose here is the one that you would mainly associate with the brand so
you know easyjet is orange uh delivery's got that teal
o2 blue for example so once we've got that we need to create
uh two color palettes here similarly to our font choices pick two um a primary palette and secondary
palette and by primary palette here i don't mean primary colors i mean the most used colors throughout
your design and secondary palette will be less commonly used and more supporting colors
and so the best way to kind of demonstrate this i think is just to show you a real world example
and how that's used so i'm going to show you uber's color palette so this is their primary color palette
it's three colors it's black white and blue um so the black and white are chosen uh
they are good pairing because they're quite contrasting colors and that means they can be used together quite easily
and remember that contrast was one of our design principles that we touched on at the start so this
is a great way of achieving contrast through color so it's important to consider that when creating your palette they also have
this third color the blue i would call this an accent color and but this is used quite frequently
throughout the brand but in a very considered way they say it's called safety blue
so it's mainly used to highlight where there's features messages alerts um or things that they really want to
highlight essentially so here's an example of that in action so the example on the left is
from the uber website they use that black and white for good contrast in the text and the
way they section out the site but then that blue is used there to kind of highlight the real key kind of offerings
and draw the eye down there and on the right is the uber app don't look at my uber rating
that you mainly uses again the black and white for contrast um but that little dot there is set in the blue to really
grab your attention and tell you that you've got a message so this is uber's secondary
color palette which you might think that doesn't look like uber's colors but they're used a lot more sparingly
around the brand especially in their illustrations which is a big part of their branding
and they're chosen to work alongside that primary color palette quite well so here we can see the colors and shades
thereof being used to communicate through illustration the palette is
used not only for contrast but it does help to find that hierarchy as well the secondary palette is supporting
elements and the primary palette is the main interface so that is a hierarchy in the
way that color is used they never really deviate from these colors um and that's what keeps the brand
recognizable um a small set of primary colors followed up by a larger set of secondary colors it's a solid approach
to creating a color palette um and that's what keeps their brand
recognizable so it's also beneficial to add some neutral
tones um this can kind of help add a bit of layering and depth
um i don't know if you can see this much on the screen but uber do use this in their app um
yeah it's a little hard to see on here these are very very light neutral tones but they use some shades of grey um
to help kind of show where there's areas of interaction and this is something that you can do
neutral doesn't necessarily just mean kind of grays either this could be kind of
shades of colors that's used in your brand palette so don't be afraid to use kind of shades throughout as well
so choosing colors yes i have a tool for that one as well this is adobe colors
every designer will use tools like this to help choose colors
and this one's great because you can kind of set that first color and start to define some palettes based
on the tools that they have here um you know you can try trial colors monochromatic different shades um it's a

well but the other good tool it has is a contrast checker for
accessibility so i know as developers you'll have a lot of technical accessibility standards to me
as designers the lowest bar to get right in terms of accessibility is getting
colors right um you know it's easy if you don't have an impaired vision to believe that certain
color combinations are fine um but we just need to ensure that there's enough contrast there
so coolers has a contrast checker but this is the one that i would typically
use um to test out colors um it lets you kind of set the foreground
background color and see what kind of standards that they pass online um
there are a lot of other people who speak in a lot more detail about accessibility but i thought this was quite important when it comes to talking
about colors to touch on this point as well

so lastly under imagery i'm going to touch on icons so iconography age old way of
communicating we see it in everyday life on signs like the exit sign in print
and digitally as well uh icons are just simple symbols to help point us in the
right direction and the benefit of using them it gives immediate context uh to the content it
sits alongside um and in digital design you'll typically see it accompanying an action or a link an
alert things like that so i just want to give you a couple of major tips when it comes to icons
because it's not really rocket science but there are some really common pitfalls um so the first is
only use an icon when it's obvious enough what it means it's very easy for us to assume that the
user will know what an icon is going to do because we know what it's going to do and i'll show you an example
of this so these are some typical icons we might see across the web
they're very familiar and users will typically understand the meaning of these
those three lines it's gonna bring up a menu magnifying glass will represent a search
and the bin is probably gonna represent a delete action uh on there so these are common icons that we all
know the meaning of um and we will call these universal icons
now let's consider what these icons might represent so these might not be as familiar might
not be as obvious in what their actions mean and while they might be a good representation for the context they're
in it might be hard for the user to understand the intention so that heart could mean like
or it could mean add to wishlist the second one that could mean a repost
or it could mean a refresh um and that last one could be a link to an faq it could bring
up a live chat um so if an icon is not clear enough what it
does give it a label and that is my big advice when it comes to using icons
it's also good for accessibility to label icons as well especially if they're not described very
well so my other tip when it comes to icons is
just keep them simple um icons need to be used at small screen sizes
and that is where detail can really get lost typically icons are quite void of detail
for this reason they use just enough pixels to communicate the point
so if i take it back to that search icon from before it's a very very basic line icon
to represent a magnifying glass but it can be recognized at loads of different sizes especially small sizes
because of its simplicity in design that is the making of a great icon

one in itself i guess um so this makes for quite a versatile layout when it

we start to build out bigger kind of elements of the interface
so when we want to build up a page it is best to start small and build up from there um components
are built up of smaller pieces and often can form repeatable elements that we we
can reuse throughout page as well so to kind of go through this i want to
briefly touch on a framework called atomic design so atomic design is a framework used to
help us break down a layout into smaller elements um the methodology uses the
following kind of items to describe how to build a component so we've got atoms molecules and
organisms and that builds up into entire page designs but what does this mean in terms
of ui so atoms these are the most basic building blocks
of an interface the kind of singular elements so in terms of the web this could be a
label it could be a text input or it could be a button
so like atoms in nature these elements are important but they're not always super useful on their own
they need to kind of merge with other atoms to become something bigger so this is where molecules come in
so molecules are where two or more atoms combine in order to create part of the interface
suddenly that label that text input or that button from before
combine to become a search bar so as you can see once we start combining these smaller elements we can
start to make bigger parts of the interface so this is a molecule um it helps to start at the bottom
not getting overwhelmed so from molecules then we can move up to
uh organisms so in a similar fashion organisms are made up of two or more
molecules so that search bar was a molecule
and that combines with other atoms or molecules and we can start to build out a header menu here
so we've got a logo we've got text links we've got that search bar you might want to add additional items here such as a

um so again this allows us to think about repeating and reusable elements as

saying that three times um that make up that molecule um so when we
